video.title: Using a Public API - Tutorial for Beginners
video.description:
Learn how to use a public API in your project. In this tutorial you will learn to use the openweathermap.org public API but everything you learn here will help you to use any other public API.

🔗Get your API Key: https://openweathermap.org/appid
🔗Icon URL: http://openweathermap.org/img/w/11d.png
🔗Using getJSON: https://api.jquery.com/jquery.getjson/
🔗Javascript Math properties: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Math

🔗Free Vectors by: https://www.vecteezy.com

⭐️Tutorial from iEatWebsites. Check out their channel for more great tutorials: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC0o60y3FtVy3M93JcDFVreA

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://medium.freecodecamp.org

topLevelComment.author: António A
topLevelComment.text: I'm not getting why it is .org/img/w? Why this path?

replies.author: Daniel Harris
replies.text: António A this is the path that openweathermap.org uses. The only thing that is dynamic is the ID that is used, then “.png” is adddd to complete the entire url to the photo.

topLevelComment.author: Scott Morgan
topLevelComment.text: .floor() will round down. You need .round() to round to the nearest degree.

replies.author: Vandelay Industries
replies.text: @TechyLeviathan 1. Don't be an ass and maybe go back to your hole in your third-world country.  2. It says for beginners. What you just said is for intermediate learners.

replies.author: TechyLeviathan
replies.text:
actually it was pretty basic.
The title said it clearly .. API for beginners. (Not HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Coding in General and CS science for beginners).  The implementation was really straight forward. If you didn't understand the other principles I suggest you to start from HTML and CSS , then JavaScript.
After a month or two of hard studying, come back and rewatch the video.

topLevelComment.author: MEXdave1997
topLevelComment.text: I liked this tutorial. The only thing that bugged me was the hardcoded url strings. In my opinion, instead of hardcoding the long url strings into the main code body, why not set them as seperate variables for cleaner looking code?

replies.author: toobstr
replies.text: Thank you! I'll check it out.

replies.author: MEXdave1997
replies.text: @toobstr go through the gist I linked. All I did was seperate the URLs as seperate variables above everything else, and then used the variables when contructing the API call

replies.author: MEXdave1997
replies.text:
To demonstrate what I mean above, here is what I ultimately ended up with that works pretty well.
https://gist.github.com/MEXdave1997/64a967d99d09b83b99ae9cb24fdc173d
